awd_titl_txt: Enhanced Efficiency in Transparent Organic Photovoltaics Using Oxide Plasmonic Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses low-cost photovoltaic (PV) thin film technology that can offer alternative methods to integrating solar energy technology into building envelops. The integration of solar-harvesting components into the building envelope is a transformative route to capturing solar energy for electricity generation while lowering effective solar cell installation costs and improving building energy efficiency. This fundamental research project addresses low-cost thin-film organic photovoltaic technology that is highly transparent in the visible light spectrum enabling integration onto windows, glazing systems, and siding in the building envelope. This project addresses fundamental research to increase the power conversion efficiency of these thin-film transparent systems by increasing absorption of near infrared light using oxide plasmonic nanoparticles embedded in the device. The research will exploit unique optical properties of oxide plasmonic nanoparticles in the near-infrared regime to enhance light absorption and power conversion efficiency. The project will also advance the fundamental understanding of oxide plasmonic nanoparticles, which are promising for a wider range of applications such as thermal management and night vision devices. The educational and outreach component of this project will train graduate and undergraduate researchers to gain a new level of understanding of light and matter at the nanometer scale.

Existing transparent organic photovoltaics have low efficiency due to the use of less than 50% of incident near-infrared sunlight. The objective of this project is to identify and understand mechanisms by which localized surface plasmon resonances of oxide plasmonic nanoparticles enhance the power conversion efficiency of transparent organic photovoltaics. With their low-concentrated free electrons and localized surface plasmon resonances in the near-infrared regime, oxide plasmonic nanoparticles will enhance near-infrared light absorption by organic thin films and the photon-current conversion in transparent organic photovoltaics while retaining visual transparency of the devices. The specific research aims include: (1) synthesize and characterize oxide plasmonic nanoparticles that support near-infrared localized surface plasmon resonances, (2) probe electron and energy transfer at the interfaces of organic thin films and oxide plasmonic nanoparticles, and (3) investigate efficiency enhancement of transparent organic photovoltaic devices that incorporate oxide plasmonic nanoparticles. The project will advance fundamental knowledge in the field of optoelectronics of oxide plasmonic nanoparticles and transparent organic photovoltaics.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
With support from NSF, Professors Yuebing Zheng and Delia Milliron at University of Texas at Austin unraveled light-matter interactions at the nanoscale and their potentials to enhance light-utilization efficiency for transparent organic photovoltaics. With their mechanical flexibility and visual transparency, transparent organic photovoltaics (TOPV) are applicable to various surfaces that are inaccessible to conventional solar cells such as screens of wearable electronic devices, automobile windows, and building windows. Common TOPV devices are consisted of transparent electrodes and organic thin films that are active in the near-infrared (NIR) part of solar spectrum. The NIR-active thin films absorb and convert NIR light into photocurrent while transmitting visible light for the visual transparency. Current TOPV devices can only absorb partially NIR light due to small thickness of the organic thin films as required for effective charge separation. As a result, TOPV devices usually exhibit low power conversion efficiency (PCE) because of the inefficient sunlight usage. It becomes critical for the organic thin films to fully absorb NIR light in order to improve the PCE in TOPV devices. With the capability of surface plasmons (SPs) in concentrating light at the subwavelength scale, plasmonic nanoparticles have been incorporated with photoactive thin films in photovoltaics to enhance the light absorption for the PCE enhancement. However, with their localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPRs) in visible-wavelength regime due to the high concentration of free electrons, conventional plasmonic nanoparticles of metals are not suitable for TOPV devices. Therefore, there remains a critical need to implement new approaches to maximize the NIR light usage in TOPV devices for the performance enhancement.

 

The researchers have successfully synthesized various metal oxide nanocrystals with strong plasmonic resonances at NIR wavelength region. Specifically, F,Sn:In2O3 nanocubes (NCs) induce a strong LSPR near-field response in the NIR range, a property that can be further amplified by creating spatially dense and tunable nanocavity arrays, without relying on size dependent tuning as in conventional Ag and Au noble metal nanomaterials. The optical properties observed in F,Sn:In2O3 NCs have the potential to be harnessed in photovoltaic applications. Coupling excitonic photoemission and LSPR near-field enhancement, derived from quantum dots and plasmonic material classes of particles, respectively, can enable photonic ?assembly of light? toward hybrid forms of light-matter interaction. In addition, the researchers have unraveled that at room temperature, optical activation of dark excitons in two-dimensional (2D) semiconductors and a dark-exciton-induced Fano interference modification can be achieved. This improves the fundamental understanding of the light-matter interaction in hybrid systems consisting of plasmonic nanoparticles and 2D semiconductors. The tuning of Fano resonance and plasmon-dark exciton coupling reveals that the coupling and energy transfer between plasmonic nanoparticles and 2D semiconductors can be optimized through rationally designing the hybrid systems. This provides us a guidance to achieving the optimized energy transfer between plasmonic nanoparticles and semiconductors with absorption peaks at NIR region and harnessing it to improve the efficiency in TOPV devices.


Last Modified: 10/08/2021
Modified by: Yuebing Zheng
